Award.AbstractNarration: Shawna McMahon will travel to Miami University in Oxford, Ohio for four days. The purpose of the trip is to meet with Dr. Ann Hagerman, view her laboratory facilities and meet with her research group, give a departmental seminar, and work on a fellowship proposal for the Polar Programs Postdoctoral Fellowships deadline (October 18, 2010).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a travel grant awarded under the Postdoctoral Fellowships in Polar Regions Research. A goal of the program is to support recent doctoral degree recipients as they pursue studies in the Arctic and further develop their skills as early career researchers. To that end, the program provides travel grants for postdocs to meet with prospective mentors, initiate collaborative relationships and develop strong proposals for the postdoctoral fellowship.

I traveled to Oxford, OH to meet with Dr. Ann Hagerman at the Miami University. Dr. Hagerman is a leader in the world of tannin chemistry. As I proposed to study tannin-protein interactions and their role in Arctic nutrient cycling, I was fortunate to have Dr. Hagerman as a mentor. This trip was a rare and truly valuable opportunity to spend several days focusing on one thing: the development of our proposal. Dr. Hagerman provided thoughtful guidance and feedback throughout the process. She helped me to see that when writing a proposal, one needs to focus carefully on the questions and hypotheses first, and then consider how those hypotheses can be tested.

The outcome of this award was the submission of a full proposal to the Postdoctoral Fellowships in Polar Regions Research in October 2010. Though the proposal was considered competitive by the panel, it was declined for funding. However, the experience was still valuable as I learned proposal-writing skills that I will continue to apply as my career proceeds. Feedback from the panelists will be invaluable as I develop this proposal into a full-scale research proposal for submission to another OPP program.
